meta.description: High-level visual and interaction design guidelines for the AI Note Synthesiser, expressed as a design-system spec. This file is written from a creative director’s perspective so it can guide future UI work, not just mirror current implementation.
designIntent: Feel like a focused, premium productivity cockpit rather than a generic dashboard.
Balance analytical clarity with a calm, low-noise visual tone.
Make AI-powered decisions feel trustworthy and explainable, not magical and opaque.
Be genuinely usable on small mobile screens, not just “responsive” on paper.

designPrinciples.clarityOverCleverness: Prioritise information hierarchy and legibility over decorative visuals. Every visual decision should make it easier to understand status, priorities, or next actions.
designPrinciples.depthNotDecor: Use the depth layer system (bg-layer-1–4, two-layer shadows) to convey structure and importance, not as eye candy. Stronger elevation means more interactivity or current focus.
designPrinciples.calmByDefault: Avoid visual noise. Keep borders subtle, rely on spacing, typography, and depth to separate sections. Use colour sparingly to call attention to decisions, errors, and key actions.
designPrinciples.trustworthyAI: When AI acts, show status, progress, and results clearly. Use consistent badges, toasts, and panels so users can trace what happened and why.
designPrinciples.mobileFirstReality: Design every surface to work comfortably at 320–414px. No horizontal scrolling, no cramped controls, and touch targets at least 44px high.
designPrinciples.oneSystemAcrossScreens: Desktop, tablet, and mobile should feel like the same product: same tokens, same component behaviours, and consistent microinteractions.
designPrinciples.motionWithPurpose: Use motion (Framer Motion, CSS transitions) to confirm state changes (uploads, status changes, AI results) and reduce cognitive load. Avoid gratuitous animation loops.

sans.name: Geist
sans.usage: Primary UI typeface for navigation, headings, labels, and body text.

mono.name: Geist Mono
mono.usage: Optional for technical snippets, IDs, and metadata when monospace improves scanability.

serif.name: System serif (e.g., Georgia)
serif.usage: Very sparingly, if at all, for narrative content or long-form documents inside the app.

display.usage: Top-level page titles (e.g., Task Priorities), mostly on desktop and tablet.

h1.usage: Primary section headers and nav brand lockup.

h2.usage: Card titles, panel headers, and important sub-sections.

body.usage: Default copy, list items, and summaries.

bodyMuted.usage: Secondary metadata, helper text, and captions.

label.usage: Form labels, badge text, and small UI labels.

responsiveGuidelines.mobileMinimum: Maintain at least 16px (1rem) for interactive form fields to prevent iOS zoom. Use `text-base sm:text-sm` patterns where inputs drop slightly on larger screens.
responsiveGuidelines.headingBehaviour: Headings may step down one size on very small screens (e.g., display → h1), but never use condensed or all-caps treatments that harm legibility.
responsiveGuidelines.truncation: Favor line-clamp (1–2 lines) over hard truncation for key statements like outcomes. Only truncate when the surrounding layout cannot gracefully expand.

tokens.primary_1: var(--primary-1) – deepest brand shade, used rarely for text or strong accents.
tokens.primary_2: var(--primary-2) – core brand colour for primary buttons, key badges, and highlights.
tokens.primary_3: var(--primary-3) – hover/active state for primary surfaces.
tokens.primary_4: var(--primary-4) – subtle tints, gradients, and backgrounds.

brand.secondaryHue: Magenta/pink accent via `--accent-secondary` to support gradients and celebratory moments.
usage: Primary CTA buttons and key AI state indicators (e.g., running analyses).
Icons in the nav logo, LNO leverage markers, and outcome highlights.
Gradients behind high-value surfaces like hero upload state or key metrics.

bg_layer_1.role: Page canvas, behind everything. Slightly tinted rather than pure white to reduce glare.

bg_layer_2.role: Primary card and header backgrounds. Feels like the main sheet the UI is printed on.

bg_layer_3.role: Interactive elements (buttons, tabs, inputs) that sit above cards.

bg_layer_4.role: Hovered, active, and highly elevated states (chips, selected tabs, focused cards).

success.usage: Completed processing, successful exports, and green-path AI outcomes.

warning.usage: Review-required states, edge-case AI confidence, or upcoming limits.

info.usage: Neutral status information, queue telemetry, and system hints.

destructive.usage: Errors, failed processing, and destructive actions like delete.

text.heading: var(--text-heading) – near-black, high contrast.
text.body: var(--text-body) – dark grey for comfortable reading.
text.muted: var(--text-muted) – secondary copy and low-priority metadata.
text.onPrimary: var(--text-on-primary) – white text on coloured surfaces.

darkMode.strategy: Invert depth layers so darker backgrounds recede and lighter surfaces indicate elevation. Brand colours brighten slightly in dark mode for equivalent contrast.
expectations: All semantic colours maintain at least AA contrast (4.5:1) against their backgrounds.
Glass effects and gradients should remain subtle; avoid neon glow.
Borders stay minimal; depth is mostly communicated through light-on-dark shadows and elevations.

grid.pageMaxWidth: max-w-7xl (~1120px) for primary surfaces like upload and dashboard.
grid.gutter: 16–24px horizontal padding on mobile, 24–32px on desktop.
grid.columns: Use 1 column on mobile, 2 columns on tablets for grids like document cards, and 3 columns only at desktop widths.

rules: 4px–8px: micro spacing between icon and label, within badges.
12px–16px: default spacing inside components (card padding, form field spacing).
24px–32px: section spacing, vertical rhythm between major blocks.

touchTargets.minimumHeight: 44px for primary interactive elements on mobile (`h-11`), 36px on desktop (`h-9`).
touchTargets.horizontalPadding: At least 12px each side for buttons and tabs.
touchTargets.hitAreaRule: Icon-only controls must still live inside 44x44px containers on mobile.

breakpoints.mobile: ≤ 414px – vertical stacking, full-width controls, no horizontal scroll.
breakpoints.tablet: 768–1024px – 2-column card grids, controls begin to align in rows.
breakpoints.desktop: ≥ 1024px – 2–3 column layouts, denser controls where appropriate.

generalGuidelines: Avoid placing more than 3 primary controls in a single row on mobile.
Prefer stacking (flex-col sm:flex-row) for complex control groups.
Use line-clamp and responsive font sizes to prevent layout breakage in long copy.

radiiAndShape.baseRadius: var(--radius) ≈ 8px; cards and dialogs typically use `rounded-xl` for a slightly softer feel.

tokens.radius_sm: Subtle rounding for input controls and pills.
tokens.radius_md: Default rounding for most components (buttons, chips).
tokens.roundedFull: Pill buttons and floating quick capture button.

radiiAndShape.philosophy: Corners are softened but not bubbly. Shapes should feel modern and precise, aligning with a productivity tool rather than a playful app.

system.shadow_2xs: Tiny internal elevation for small surfaces.
system.shadow_xs_sm: Default card and nav bar elevation using two-layer system (inset highlight + soft drop shadow).
system.shadow_md_lg: Used sparingly for modals, floating actions (Quick Capture), and elevated interactive panels.

elevationClasses.shadow-2layer-sm: Small depth for nav, small cards, and chips.
elevationClasses.shadow-2layer-md: Standard depth for primary cards and dropdowns.
elevationClasses.shadow-2layer-lg: Prominent depth for hover and focus states of key interactive surfaces.

behaviour.hoverLift: Use `.hover-lift` or `.hover-shadow-lift` to subtly raise cards and buttons on hover.
behaviour.consistency: Avoid mixing raw Tailwind shadows with custom two-layer shadows; prefer the custom utilities for a coherent look.

principles.confirmActions: Uploads starting, AI orchestration, and state transitions should always have visible feedback via loaders, toasts, or card animation.
principles.keepSnappy: Animations should generally complete within 150–300ms. Ease-out for entrances, ease-in for exits.
principles.avoidOverload: Do not animate more than one major property (scale, opacity, position) at once on dense screens.

usagePatterns.listsAndCards: Fade/slide in for new file cards and AI summaries using Framer Motion; minimal bounce for a professional feel.
usagePatterns.statusChanges: Badges and status labels may crossfade or slide; avoid jarring reflows.
usagePatterns.modalsAndDrawers: Use scale+opacity transitions for dialogs; slide for drawers on mobile.

focusManagement.focusRings: Use `focus-visible:ring-[3px]` with `var(--border-focus)` for all keyboard-focusable elements.
focusManagement.skipHoverOnly: Do not rely on hover colour alone to show interactive state; combine with shape, shadow, or underlines.

stateCommunication.statuses: Use consistent badge styles for states (uploading, pending, processing, completed, failed, review_required). Combine icons and verbs (e.g., ‘Processing’).
stateCommunication.toasts: Use `sonner` to present time-bounded feedback (summary ready, failure, network issues). Toasts must never be the only place critical errors are shown.

mobileSpecific.noHorizontalScroll: Primary experiences (upload, dashboard, priorities, outcome builder) must never require horizontal scrolling at mobile widths.
mobileSpecific.gestureFriendly: Controls that appear near screen edges should have padding to avoid accidental OS gesture conflicts.

Button.role: Primary interactive element for actions across the app.

variants.default: Solid primary button using `bg-primary-2` with white text. Used for key actions like Analyze Tasks, Quick Capture, and primary confirmations.
variants.outline: Neutral background (`bg-bg-layer-3`) with subtle shadow and no visible border. Used for secondary CTAs, filters, and navigation actions.
variants.secondary: Subtle background (`bg-bg-layer-2`) for neutral actions within cards and panels.
variants.ghost: Minimal chrome, used for icon or tertiary actions in dense layouts (e.g., overflow menus).
variants.destructive: Red semantic surface for irreversible operations like delete.
variants.link: Text-style button, used sparingly where navigation semantics matter more than ‘action’ semantics.

sizes.default: Desktop: h-9, Mobile: h-11 via `h-11 sm:h-9`. Horizontal padding: 16–24px.
sizes.sm: Only used where density is essential; avoid on mobile for primary actions.
sizes.lg: Prominent call-to-action (e.g., Quick Capture floating button).
sizes.icon: Square buttons used with clear iconography and tooltips; always wrapped in 44px hit areas on mobile.

Button.responsiveness: Stacks into full-width buttons on mobile for multi-action bars (e.g., bulk export, modal footers).
principles: Every screen should have at most one visually dominant primary button.
Label verbs should be concrete and outcome-oriented (e.g., ‘Analyze Tasks’, ‘Upload Documents’).

Badge.role: Compact status and count indicators for files, AI confidence, LNO classes, and document counts.

variants.default: Primary-coloured badges for most-prominent labels (e.g., Leverage count).
variants.secondary: Neutral badges for metadata counts and filters.
variants.outline: Lightly elevated chip for summary metadata (e.g., queue summaries).
variants.destructive: Red-tinted backgrounds for failure or exclusion indicators.

Badge.behaviour: Badges should never be the only place a user can discover a critical state; they are visual summaries that reinforce text nearby.

Card.role: Primary content container for documents, summaries, outcomes, and dashboards.
Card.visualStyle: Rounded-xl, background at bg-layer-2, two-layer shadow by default with hover lift. Minimal borders.
usage: Document tiles in dashboard with clear title, metadata, status badges, and actions.
Context cards (reflections, outcomes) that summarise the current strategic direction.

Input.role: Single-line text entry for object, metric, capacity, and filters.
Input.visualStyle: Transparent background, subtle border using `border-input`, focus ring at 3px with brand colour. Light background overlay in dark mode.
Input.behaviour: Always accompanied by a label and potential helper text; error states show in red with `aria-invalid` and visible text.
Input.mobile: Use 16px font size and `h-12 sm:h-10` to avoid zoom and ensure comfortable tapping.

Textarea.role: Multi-line text for reflections, clarifiers, and notes.
Textarea.visualStyle: Matches Input but with taller content area and flexible height; uses the same border and focus behaviours.
guidelines: Line length should remain comfortable; use max-width containers and avoid full-bleed text.
Offer character counters for fields with limits (e.g., clarifier), and keep helper text concise.

Tabs.role: Switch between related views in a constrained area (e.g., SummaryPanel tabs, dashboard filters).
Tabs.visualStyle: Pill-like triggers on a muted background, with active tab appearing raised with background contrast and subtle shadow.
Tabs.responsiveness: TabsList should wrap gracefully and, on small screens, use smaller text and potentially icon-plus-label or icon-only treatments where space is tight.

Alert.role: Inline messaging for errors, warnings, and informational notices.

variants.default: Neutral panel for non-critical messages and guidance.
variants.destructive: Error-focused, using destructive colour tokens, and emphasising the description.

Alert.usage: Prefer inline alerts in context (inside cards or modals) rather than global banners unless the entire workflow is blocked.

Dialog.role: Blocking interactions where users must focus on one structured flow (e.g., OutcomeBuilder, text input modals).
Dialog.visualStyle: Centered over semi-opaque dark overlay; rounded corners, high elevation shadow. Content scrollable when long, with sticky footers where needed.
mobileGuidelines: Max height near 90–95vh with generous internal padding that adapts to small screens.
Buttons in the footer should be full-width on mobile and comfortably spaced.
Avoid cramming too many form fields; group and sequence where necessary.

Drawer.role: Non-blocking, contextual surfaces that slide in, primarily for mobile (e.g., detail views, filters).
Drawer.expectations: Use sparingly. Content should be concise and easily dismissible; main actions remain within reach of thumb on mobile.

DropdownMenu.role: Compact menus for per-item actions (e.g., document reprocess/delete).
DropdownMenu.behaviour: Always anchored to a clearly identifiable trigger (icon button). Items use concise verbs and include icons where helpful.
DropdownMenu.accessibility: Ensure proper ARIA roles and keyboard navigation via shadcn/Radix defaults.

Switch.role: Binary toggles for persistent settings (e.g., sync on/off).
Switch.visualStyle: Rounded track with clear thumb, using semantic colours on checked state. Label should be adjacent and clearly describe what is toggled.

Checkbox.role: Multi-select within lists (e.g., selecting documents for bulk export).
Checkbox.mobileGuidelines: Increase tap area (`h-5 w-5` on mobile) and pair with labels and spacing to avoid accidental taps.
Checkbox.usage: Use primarily in contexts where bulk actions are clearly visible and explained.

Tooltip.role: Clarify icon-only actions and subtle controls.
Tooltip.behaviour: Appear on hover and focus; content should be short, action-oriented, and never critical to task completion.

Toast.role: Transient notifications for success, failure, or background progress updates.
Toast.style: Use subtle depth and semantic colours; multiple toasts should stack but not cover primary controls.
Toast.usage: Reserve toasts for events that just occurred, not reminders or persistent states.

Skeleton.role: Loading placeholders for cards and lists while data is fetched.
Skeleton.style: Soft edges and muted colours aligned with bg-layer-3; shimmer effects, if used, should be subtle and not distracting.

Nav_Main.role: Top-level navigation across Upload, Dashboard, and Task Priorities.
Nav_Main.visualStyle: Sticky top bar with bg-layer-2, two-layer shadow, and brand lockup on the left. Tabs-like nav items with clear active states.
Nav_Main.behaviour: On mobile, nav remains slim and scannable; brand text may truncate, but the app name should remain recognisable.

QuickCapture.role: Floating CTA to capture thoughts or text from any page.
QuickCapture.visualStyle: Rounded-full primary button anchored bottom-right with strong elevation and clear icon+label (‘Quick Capture’).
principles: Visible but not overwhelming; should not cover critical content.
Always available on primary screens, reinforcing the app’s ‘capture-first’ workflow.

OutcomeBanner.role: Persistent, subtle reminder of the active outcome driving AI decisions.
OutcomeBanner.visualStyle: Thin strip at the top of relevant pages, with icon, outcome sentence, and lightweight edit affordance.
OutcomeBanner.mobileGuidelines: Allow two lines of text via line-clamp, avoid truncation that removes meaning, and ensure the edit action remains tappable.

UploadFlow.purpose: Ingest user documents in a calm, reassuring way that sets expectations about processing.
structure: Header with brand and quick access to reflections/outcome.
Hero upload card with large dropzone and simple copy.
Queue summary and file list with clear statuses and eventual summaries.
UploadFlow.tone: Reassuring and explanatory. Users should never wonder what to do next or whether the system is working.

Dashboard.purpose: Provide a bird’s-eye view of documents and their AI summaries, with bulk operations and exports.
structure: Filter and sort controls in a flexible, stackable layout.
Document grid of cards with consistent metadata and actions.
Dashboard.interactionModel: Scan → filter/sort → expand a card for depth → export or reprocess.

TaskPriorities.purpose: Express AI-prioritised tasks as a focused, dependency-aware plan with visual supports.
structure: Context card for reflections and outcome state.
Primary analysis card to run or rerun prioritisation.
Task list with movement markers, LNO classification, and strategic scores.
Quadrant visualization to make impact/effort relationships visible at a glance.
TaskPriorities.tone: Analytical but not intimidating. The user should feel guided by the system, not overruled.
